Post Text: 7 reframes you NEED as an employee if you want to become an owner:1. You’ll never be a good entrepreneur if you can’t solve problems at your job.2. Post Text: I have a friend who is 40 and damn near a billionaire.I asked him what his one key to investing well is...Here's what he told me:We have a habit of late nights, good wine, and tough questions about the world around us. One night I was candid asking how he made his fortune. I was looking for things to replicate...The simplicity of his reply surprised me.“I train my brain to perform one task incredibly well. One task alone... to never conform.”Here's how he explained it:The Funnel to Nonconformity:+Become a funnel for ideas+Let ideas fight based on merit, not emotion+Find courage to act in nonconformity= Opportunities others never see, or are too scared to act upon #1 Don’t Believe In Anger:Anger is a trick of the mind pushing you into a fight or flight. Let me tell you what you can’t do well when you’re fighting or flighting... think. Remove your anger.#2 The Controversy & Conformity Conundrum:There is a spectrum where controversies and conformity sit on opposite ends. Most of the wins in life land on the edge of controversy. Choose your controversy wisely, but choose it.#3 Reading As A Diet:Be careful what you read, it becomes the way you think. Curate what you let into your brain as you do with your body.#4 Ideas Strongly Stated & Loosely Held:Having a strong opinion is the mark of intellect but having the ability to change it is the mark of true intelligence.#5 Share Your MVPs:Every time you produce a product or idea, more come back ten-fold. So don’t make it perfect, make it done. Then let the market decide.#6 Warren Buffet Doesn’t Optimize:Wake up at 5 am, meditate, work out, drink 72 ounces of chloride water and stand upside down. Or... do none of those things and instead focus on thinking clearly, intently, and strategically before you pull any triggers.#7 Boredom As a Superpower:The best ideas need breathing room. They’re a flower stretching for the sun. Clutter them with meetings, and watch them die.#8 Numbers > Narrative:Anytime something is common practice, check if it’s common sense. Return to the very first principle there is: 1+1 = 2. Numbers are often terrible liars.#9 Can You Explain it to Grandma?Can you take the complex and make it simple? If not, you don’t know enough. Strong beliefs paired with little knowledge is a dangerous spot to operate.#10 Every New Learning Is A Little Death:Your skin regenerates itself every 72 days. Your ideas need an equal level of regeneration. Challenge old ideas and let them be reborn into something better.Finally, I'll leave you with this:“A contrarian isn’t one who always objects — that’s a conformist of a different sort. Post Text: Amazon is facing an $8B/year problem.  • ~75% of employees leave the company • Only 1/3 of new hires stay for >90 days • 100% employee turnover in warehouses (double the industry average)  But it gets even worse.  Let me explain:   So, how big of a problem is losing $8B/yr? For context, Amazon’s net income: • In 2021, was $33.36B • In 2022, was -$2.72B  But there’s a conundrum bigger than money:  Amazon could RUN OUT of people to hire in its US warehouses by 2024.  At one point, employee turnover was seen as an advantage to Amazon. Bezos saw his warehouse workforce as necessary - but replaceable.  He can't afford to think that way anymore.  What’s causing such low satisfaction?  Sure, there are surface-level factors: • High-pressure environments • Tough working conditions • Poor work-life balance  But lots of hard jobs have happy employees.  There's a bigger underlying problem...  The industrial mindset.  Amazon would rather have employees: • Robotically produce output • Have no say in operations • Receive no benefits • Follow instructions • Get no promotions  Employees have NO skin in the game.  There's a systemic failure bigger than Amazon...  We’ve become a nation of renters, owned by an elite group of owners.  We’ve handed our lives to those who tell us we must be protected – not protectors.  “You will own nothing and be happy about it.”   Centralization at the crux of the issue. Our banks, corporations, stock market, governments...  Everything is centralized.  Centralization breeds bureaucracies. Bureaucracies care little for you.  You become a cog in an endless machine.  Humans were meant to be tribal groups where our activities meant something. Now we: • Work where we can't feel our impact • Buy from companies we know no one at • Hardly know our neighbors  You make poor decisions when you’re not responsible for the outcome.  Amazon’s problem should open our eyes.  Decentralize. Build small. Buy small. Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: Waking up at 5:45am solves 99.9% of daily issues.  12 other unreasonably simple habits to change your life:  1. Grab your to-do list. Do the thing you want to do least, first.  2. Stop all 60 min meetings, make them 45 minutes. Tighter meetings, more time.  3. No social media, email, or text when you wake up. Write something, read something, or create something before you get sucked in.  4. Do the $1,000/hr Test. Group work in 3 buckets based on return: $10, $100, $1,000. Offload one low ROI task per day.  5. Change one meeting a week to a walking call. Watch how excited the other meeting member becomes.  6. Add a How vs Won't check-in. When you say, "that WON'T work." Instead ask, "How could that work?"  7. Be the dumbest one in your friend group, then move on when you’re not. As they say, if you’re the smartest person in the room, you’re in the wrong room.  8. Take a picture of your net worth. What gets measured gets managed. Check finances daily.  9. Always the stairs, never the elevator. Pick the hard option. See how much stronger you are than you think.  10. Never write to-dos in stone. You're 10x more productive if you reprioritize daily.  11. Meditate. 10 minutes a day. For a twofer - do it in the sauna. Sometimes hacking culture gets it right.  12. Get intimidated. Everything you want is on the other side of fear. Do something every day that scares you a little bit.  Life is the small things repeated daily.  Change one daily habit, and beautiful things start to happen...  So pick one.↓ ↓ ↓If you need more high-leverage habits, frameworks, and general kicks in the *ss... you might like my newsletter → https://lnkd.in/g3smakQm

Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: I found a business making >$3.5M/year selling wooden sunglasses.  They’ve got only one employee:  The founder’s mom.  Here’s the breakdown:  Meet Cory Stout. He’s a born hustler:  1) Made $1,000s scalping football tickets 2) Pocketed ~$15k selling watches from China 3) Started Woodies Sunglasses at 28 w/ the profits  Cory’s best friend, Mike, studied in China.  One time, while visiting Mike, he realized: products hit markets in Guangzhou before they hit the rest of the world.  He saw that wooden sunglasses hadn’t taken off in the US yet, and got to work.  To kick things off, Cory had: • A team in China handling production • A contact at Groupon who helped launch • A $180k investment between Cory & 2 others  Here’s what he did to scale his biz:  1. Factories in China  Cory’s pro tip for choosing the right factory?  Use their bathroom.  If the bathroom resembles a warzone, stay away.  Factories have millions of dollars in machinery – if they don’t invest in their workers, they’re likely corner-cutters.  2. Kendall Jenner  Yes, Kendall Jenner.  Cory tracked down Jenner’s manager to ask her rate for a photoshoot campaign.  It was a pure shot in the dark.  The result?  He somehow negotiated her down from $150k to just $25k + incentives – a SIXTH of the original price.  3. Amazon  As Woodies started selling on Amazon, Cody became a marketing maestro.  Now, Amazon makes up close to 95% of sales.  Cory's advice: “If you master Amazon, you’re set for life.”  He dropped a mega Reddit post with 30+ tips to rank higher on Amazon. Here are 3 of his “essential” tips: • Don't violate Amazon TOS, no matter what • Don’t stockout (and if you DO, definitely DON'T raise your price right before) • Do everything to avoid 1-star reviews  4. Mom’s the Word  My favorite thing about this business:  Cory hired his mom, Pamela, to manage customer service. And she excelled – her skills drove tons of 5-star reviews to his pages.  As of 2022, Cory has made her CEO.  She still answers every customer email.  5. Simplicity  Cory comes from the 4-Hour Workweek school of thought.  Naturally, he hates complexity and outsources wherever possible. He doesn’t sell on eBay, Etsy, or retail stores. In fact, he doesn’t sell anywhere outside the US as it’s too complicated.  Lastly, Cory’s number 1 piece of advice to budding entrepreneurs?  “Just make sure you love what you’re working on. Life’s too short.”

Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: Story from my dad today.  If you’re a business owner, it may hit you as deeply as it hit me...  He said, you know you’ve met another builder or doer when they’ve felt that flinch at the second Friday of the month.  My father has never bounced a check.  But he remembers this…  It was payday, his business was owed money, and they couldn’t bridge the gap between the two in time.  He could just picture the guys’ faces.  Those last two workers, who had done more than anyone else, stayed later than anyone else…  And they were about to be punished for that by not getting paid.  So he called up his banker, told him he needed a line of credit, and pulled out $100,000 give or take to make sure that every single one of their checks cleared.  At the time, my dad had a business partner who was a different type of guy.  He was the sort to make excuses, pay himself first, and not particularly care if everyone else’s checks cleared as long as he got his.  That partner has since had many businesses fail - and many more employees go without a paycheck.  And my dad has never in all these years had a business fail, or lost anyone a dime.  He often attributes his business success to the fact that he would never let his hardest working guys go hungry...  People will always be your biggest struggle and your greatest gift in business. Treat ‘em right.↓ ↓ ↓You’ll always recognize another builder.But if you see yourself in this story a little TOO much, it might be time for cashflow tracking.This one spreadsheet has saved my a** countless times to meet payroll comfortably every month. Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: We’ve completely forgotten why we're entrepreneurs.  When did we become a group of vitamin-D-deprived, Allbird-wearing, alternative-milk-drinking, extreme PowerPointers?  Many of us got soft.  We don’t climb mountains, we only take risks with other people’s money, we sit behind keyboards bragging about how ChatGPT did all the work.  What a terrible thing to strive for.  How can you make the most money by employing the fewest people and doing the least amount of work? How can you get mailbox money? Or a fast exit so you can tweet about it?  The secret:  Entrepreneurs don’t exist just for a bunch of zero’s and some big exit, but because we are crazy people willing things into very existence.  We are supposed to be the next generation of explorers, risk-takers, adrenaline junkies. Addicts to the masochistic mission of achievement and ownership.  The feeling of being so damn unemployable your only option is owner. The inability to sleep because of visions so big they pull you from bed in the dead of the night. Dreams so futuristic people laugh when you tell them.  Those are the entrepreneurs I admire.  My husband and I have a saying:  “Protect those who can’t, cast aside those who won’t, enable those who want.”  Here’s to all of you who want so badly your wants become realities.

Post Text: The #1 killer of businesses is bad cashflow.  15 other harsh business truths for you:  1. The greatest muscle you can build is urgency. Bureaucracy is business poison.  2. Post Text: Ever heard of Native deodorant?  Their story's wild: • Exited for $100M • Within 2.5 years  What's even crazier: • They ONLY raised $500k total  It's the kind of biz that inspires you to just START something... Here's the story:  Moiz Ali got the idea for Native after reading the back of an Axe can.  He had no clue what the ingredients were.  At the time, he knew "natural" products were on the rise (natural deodorant was the number 1 product on Etsy in 2015).  And so...  He decided to start a natural deodorant company.  Bear in mind - at this point, Moiz knows NOTHING about deodorant.  His reaction is one of the reasons I love this story – it shows how important mindset is in business:  “I know nothing, and in six months, I’m going to become one of the world’s leading experts on deodorant. I’m just going to spend my time learning, and I’m going to figure it out.”  So - how did Moiz make the first bar of Native?  He went on Etsy, found the best makers of natural deodorant & asked to white label their product.  And as is often the case, it took dozens of no's before one person agreed.  At this point, Moiz launched on Product Hunt. With no deodorant in hand, he sold his first 60 units.  That's when he ACTUALLY put in the first order.  This is a theme in business success stories: lowering risk by testing the market before committing. Worst possible case? He's in the hole a couple hundred $.  Another thing Moiz did right?  Hyper-focus on customers.  Despite early traction, he quickly realized the first product wasn't great.  So he spent the first year fine-tuning the product – by sending out free samples & iterating on feedback.  The results?  Native went from a 4-star rating & 25% repeat order rate to a 4.7 rating & 50% repeat order rate.  Moiz scaled the biz from $50k revenue in Jan 2016 to $1M in Nov of the same year.  Other ways they grew so fast:  • Launching subscription plans • Customer video testimonials as ads • Upgrading customer experience (sending fun emails & cards with purchases)  In 2017, Native had hit between $25-35M in revenue – with ONLY 8 fulltime employees.  They were acquired by P&G for $100M.  This was the first purchase P&G had made in 10 years.  Moiz says there were 4 main reasons he went with P&G: • Value alignment during negotiation (no over-the-top diligence requests & respecting Moiz's vision) • The dedication P&G showed in their work • Alignment on brand & creative • Resources for future growth  I'm inspired by this story: • Moiz knowing nothing but picking a simple biz model • His obsession with customers • How insanely fast they grew • The care behind the exit  It makes you think... "I could make it if I just took the leap."  ↓  If you enjoyed this story, feel free to repost & follow for more.

Post Text: Costco’s 2022 revenue was $227 BILLION.Their business model is genius – but what if you could apply it elsewhere?Well, a company raised $100M by applying Costco’s biz model to makeup.Meet Beauty Pie:First off, why is Costco so successful?It's not as simple as "wholesale."It's even simpler: cheap prices.Retail markups average around 30-60%. But Costco caps markups on national brands at 14% & their house brand, Kirkland, at 15%.How can it justify such low prices? That's where membership fees come in.In 2022, their membership fee revenue alone was $4.22B.It's genius: customers shop at Costco to justify the membership cost – which ensures repeat visits.While they make a lower profit per item, high sales volumes offset low margins. Notably, Costco retains ~90% of their customers each year.Companies have tried to replicate the low-markup membership model before...But few have done as well as Beauty Pie.They've taken Costco's business model and applied it to cosmetics.Here's how it works: Markups in beauty are especially crazy – sometimes up to 10x cost because of customer perceptions of luxury:• Huge marketing & advertising costs (think endorsements)• Expensive, fancy packaging• High-end retail storesBeauty Pie have done the exact opposite... For $59 a year, you can choose from ~400 high-end makeup, skincare, and hair products at "factory prices."And they can sell at these prices by:• Having plain & uniform packaging• No brick-and-mortar stores• Low marketing spend And it's working:• 40% growth in membership last year• Estimated $50-100M revenue last year• Raised $170M to date (including $100M Series B in 2021) I'm a fan of this company for 2 reasons.1) They're reinventing perceptions of an industry.People see cosmetics as luxury goods - they need to be wooed by glitzy advertising & endorsements.But Beauty Pie is the cosmetic industry's answer to product-led growth. 2) Other companies have tried to emulate the "Costco model" – but not all of them worked (ever heard of Brandless?).I love that Beauty Pie found a viable new industry for the low-markup model, but it got me thinking:Where else might this business model work well? It's got to be an industry with:• High markups that can be eliminated (eg retail stores, advertising spend, etc)• A product consumers buy multiple times a year (or a multi-product offering so a membership makes sense)• Low brand loyalty (ie, best value wins)So ...Any brilliant Costco-style biz ideas? Despite knowing next to nothing about aviation, Jesse helped the private jet giant reach billions in revenue, eventually selling to Berkshire Hathaway in 2010.  Here are the key lessons from his journey:  1. Small swings lead to big wins  One of Jesse's first biz ideas was collaborating with the NY Knicks on an arena anthem song. Which paid off.  Case in point: he got the president of NetJets to give Marquis a shot.  He'd apparently done the guy a favor years before by getting his daughter Christina Aguilera tickets.  3. The best learning comes by doing  Marquis Jet took off despite Jesse having zero aviation experience to start.   He spent weeks taking meetings and soaking up industry knowledge from NetJets in preparation for the launch.  Start first, then learn.  4. Expand your comfort zone  Bored in his late 30s, Jesse had the idea to ask David Goggins to live with him.  He wrote about the intense month in his book “Living with a Seal.”  Wild experience where he learned to approach life with an “all-in” mindset.  5. You'll fail, so fail fast  Jesse's first music release kinda failed.  His debut album peaked at #74 on the charts, and only because of the 1 hit.  Rather than dwelling, he immediately shifted to writing pop songs for other artists. When in doubt, pivot.  6. Partners can make or break a biz  Lucky for Jesse, his partners were great.  A huge part of his success was in co-founding the sports licensing label & Marquis Jets.  Find complementary partners.  7. Post Text: In the 1980s, this one mistake cost AT&T $12.6B... And you've probably done it too.  Here's what it was (& how you can avoid it):   It's called "assumed constraints."  Ever seen elephants in a safari/zoo? Have you noticed how they're restrained?  It's often nothing more than a metal chain bound to a peg in the ground.  Nothing for a 12,000-pound beast who wants to break loose, right?  But here's the thing:  When that elephant was a baby, the same chain & peg was used to hold it in place.  Back then, that was sufficient to restrain it. When the baby elephant would try and break away, the metal would cut into its skin, wounding it...   As it grows, it never forgets the pain of the chain (elephants never forget, right?).  So it thinks it's impossible to break away.  These are "assumed constraints" – irrational, limiting beliefs.  But you're not an elephant. So what does this matter?  Let's look at some biz examples...   1. McKinsey-AT&T  In the 80s, McKinsey estimated less than 900k people would use cellphones by 2000. They thought it'd be a "niche market."  They suggested AT&T not pursue cellular.  But by 2000, there were ~100 MILLION users. And AT&T had to acquire McCaw Cellular for $12.6B to rectify the mistake.   2. Uber  In 2014, valuation expert A. Damodaran said Uber was worth $5.9B. Maximum.  Its actual worth today? $95billion-ish.  He assumed Uber's primary market was the global taxi market. Don't know about you, but... I use Uber way more than I used taxis.  Pricing a disruptor based on an existing market = assumed constraint.  3. Computers  Thomas Watson, president of IBM, said in 1943: "I think there is a world market for maybe five computers."  A few decades later, Bill Gates said, "640Kb of memory should be enough for everyone."  The computer you're reading this on has at LEAST 7,000x that power.  Technology is where most of the world's assumed constraints manifest.  ↓ ↓ ↓  SO, how do you avoid using assumed constraints?  When approaching any problem, list ALL of your initial assumptions.  Go through each and ask:  • Who's imposing this on me? • How can I verify if this is true? • What would change if this weren't true?  You'll think 10x bigger immediately.  Question everything. Break the problem down into components, so you never miss a thing.

Post Text: I just heard about this biz... • Today: worth over $42billion • To start: a $75,000 JUNKYARD  It became the titan it is today through big bets, unique incentives, and acquisitions.  Here’s the story of Copart:  Willis Johnson had a background as an auto dismantler.  At 34, after ten years in the auto salvage business, Johnson bought his first junkyard for $75,000.  At the time, salvage vehicles were mainly auctioned to licensed dealers. Johnson did something different...  He wanted to create a platform that would allow ANYONE to bid on & purchase these vehicles.  So, Copart was born.  The company started small, with just 1 location and a handful of employees. But word of mouth about their unique business model spread...  Previously, salvagers got a fixed fee from sellers to sell a car. Copart took a percentage (~15%) per vehicle instead.  This meant they had a vested interest in maximizing resale value – they'd even clean & repair vehicles to get better prices.  In the following 11 years, they: • Opened 11 additional locations • Eventually launching nationwide  This fueled an astonishing average annual growth of 100%+ in the 90s.  But the real turning point came in 1995: As the internet crept into relevance, Copart made a big bet... They launched an online auction platform.  Now anyone could bid on cars remotely. Their reach skyrocketed.  This, combined with acquisitions (their biggest growth lever), propelled the biz. Sales jumped from: • $6M in 1992 • To $126M by 1997  They began international expansion, in the UK first & now ~200 locations globally.  They've become a mammoth of a biz: • Worth ~$40B • Revenue of ~$1B • Sell 265k+ vehicles per year  I love this biz for several reasons:  1. The 'rollup' model  This is the process of Copart slowly buying more and more locations to become a formidable force.  This can't be replicated in all industries (predominantly brick-and-mortar).  But when it works, it compounds FAST.  2. Innovative biz model  Can you think of any current industry where a small incentives tweak would result in better outcomes for all parties involved?  Copart's % fee change was genius because it meant when Copart succeeded, so did buyers & sellers.  3. Big bets  Embracing early tech can be risky.  The companies that get it right go on to rule the world.↓ ↓ ↓Thanks for reading. If you like business breakdowns like this, my newsletter has even deeper dives. Post Text: You probably know of Dollar Shave Club.What you might not know?Unilever bought them for $1B. And the acquisition was deemed a failure.Here's the lowdown:Michael Dubin, a stand-up comedian & digital marketer who'd just lost his job, met Mark Levine at a party.It came out that Mark had a unique problem: a surplus of 250,000 razors.He desperately needed help selling them.This inspired an idea in Michael's mind...What if he started a service that cut the expense & hassle of razor blades?What if they just showed up at your door each month – for $1 each?Given his passion for improv & marketing experience, Michael decided to create a launch video to differentiate their brand.What resulted was one of the greatest video ads of all time: https://lnkd.in/eFzVVVSHThat video went CRAZY viral.It generated 12k $1/mo subscriptions within 48hrs & racked up 4.75M views in 3 months.But why did it work so well?Great storytelling:• Michael is the hero & protagonist• Us vs them narrative, where Big Razor is the enemy• And of course, a level of humor Gillette could never hope to reach. By 2016, DSC was doing $153M with 3.2M members. They had an estimated 10% of the US razor market.Happy ending. ...Right?Meanwhile, P&G-owned Gillette slowed. Of the men's razor market, they owned:• 70% in 2010• 54% in 2016In response, they launched a knockoff subscription ("Gillette On-Demand").P&G's rival, Unilever, took notice...In 2016, Unilever bought Dollar Shave Club for $1B – one of the largest e-commerce transactions at the time.So... was it a success?It's D2C standard to balance customer acquisition costs with how much customers spend in a year. But Dollar Shave Club was using a 5 year timeline.Aka, spending 5 TIMES AS MUCH on customer acquisition as they should have.This made profitability elusive.To counter this, they expanded their product line since the acquistion.Including $50 cologne, $10 hair cream, $13 sunscreen... But wait, what was DSC's original hook?$1 razors...DSC's legacy customers don't spend on higher-end (high-margin) products. Meaning: Unilever didn't study their customer enough.Also, DSC was paid for entirely in cash.Michael's upfront payout was ~$90M.He contractually had to stay on as CEO for a period, but this payment structure gave him little incentive to continue growing the business (vs equity, for example).For these reasons, Unilever themselves said last year:"Dollar Shave Club has not delivered the results they were expecting."But, it's still a functioning business. DSC hasn't totally failed, and Unilever could still turn things around...If you found this story interesting, feel free to repost & follow me Codie A. Sanchez for more.

Post Text: A data-backed cheat code you’ll wish you knew 10 years ago:  It’s called the Spillover Effect.  Kellogg Insight did a study across 58,000 hours in 11 companies about high performers and low performers.  This is what they found:  1. Positive Spillover  If you sit within 25ft of a high performer, your performance increases by 15%.  Translated financially, if you make $100k a year, you start making 115k.  You are no smarter, you work no harder... and you're 15% better.  Plus, the highest performers are not negatively impacted if their neighbors are performing lower. The strong always lift up the weak.  2. Negative Spillover  But if you sit near a bad performer… Things get bad fast.  But how they define “low performer” in the study is important... They call them "toxic workers," which is someone who ends up being fired for their behavior/performance.  On average: • A toxic worker costs a company $12,800. • 2% of all workers are toxic. • They infect FAST.  The poison of a toxic worker spans way beyond 25ft:  Researchers said, “You can see their negative imprint and negative effect across an entire floor.”  2 takeaways here for you:  1. Post Text: How much does it ACTUALLY cost to start & scale a $20k/month business?  A Reddit user broke down how he did it with "inventrepreneurship."  Here’s how it went down:  1. Ideation: $0  Our inventor is Chris. Here’s how he started:  • Had a household appliance issue • Saw YouTube videos on the issue with 100k+ views • But solutions required DIY/buying parts • No easy solution on Amazon either  Like that, he had his idea + market validation.  2. Design: $363.33  Chris found a local 3D printing business.  They turned his verbal descriptions into 3D computer-aided design prototypes.  Transforming mental images into legit designs (e.g. to give factories) cost ~$400. Not bad.  3. Admin & Paperwork: $130 (+$2,500 optional)  $130 to set up a business: • EIN → free (via the IRS site) • Name filing fee → $45 • LLC filing fee → $50 + $35 for expedited service  The optional $2,500? Patent protection.  Chris waited until his sales could fund this bit.  4. Mass production: $4,600  Chris found Alibaba suppliers that worked with the materials he needed.  He chose one that had quality and experience – not just a low price.  They pointed out issues with the design other companies missed. He felt they knew what they were doing.   The $4,600 breaks down into: • $4,350 for 1,000 units • $50 to ship one initial, test prototype from China to the US • $200 to ship the full batch of units  After this, Chris was ready to start selling.   5. Sales: $392 (+ variable fees)  • Wix for 1 year: $102 (with 50% coupon) • Amazon seller account: $40 • 10 UPCs: $250 via GS1 (the official barcode establishment required by Amazon)  Variable costs: • Amazon fees + packaging: ~$6 per sale   The results?  The guy’s chosen to keep himself, and his biz, anonymous – so, unfortunately, there’s no super recent data.  But, after one year:  • Selling in 8 countries • $40 price per unit • ~$7 cost per unit • ~$5,000 in profit/week  All from a little over $5,500 in startup costs.  Pricier to start than dropshipping? A bit. More work? Sure.  But between: • The patent • His anonymity • Custom manufacturing • Not sharing the parts' design details  No one's gonna be copycatting Chris's idea.

Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: It was 2008 during the financial crisis.  I was sitting at Goldman Sachs watching people pack up everything they owned into cardboard boxes as 20% of the workforce was fired.  People were crying, protestors outside were chanting “F*ck the 1%” as they left. It was awful.  But as I sat outside one of the glass offices where they fired people, I got to overhear something...  They were firing one of the managing directors, head guys... and he wasn’t crying.  In fact, he was pretty stoic and they were going back and forth over a piece of paper.  On it, I’d find out later, was his equity % that he’d get in the firm. They were explaining to him what his exit package would be. He was getting paid to leave and not work. That pay included him owning part of the company after he left.   His name was Jim, and he was paid millions over the next few years.  I heard someone say once that they made more than the CEO of a bunch of companies, including Ford, in 1 year. Hmmmm. That would be a lot of money. That would surprise me… So I went to look up the numbers. Because, well, math always wins.   So Ford’s CEO’s salary was $1.7 million. Ok, I make more than that too.   But wait a second… his TOTAL compensation was $20.9M. I do not make more than that a year.   Goldman Sachs’s CEO’s salary is $2M a year. Wow, I make more than that. But wait… all in he makes $25-35Million. I don’t take home that… yet.  Here’s the problem most people do not understand:  Wealth will never come from a salary. It only comes through ownership.  There are only 4 ways to get ownership:  1. Start your own company 2. Become such a valuable employee to a company you’re irreplaceable (and get equity for it) 3. Invest in a company 4. Buy a company like you buy a house  You can work hard for a paycheck, or you can work hard for ownership.  It’s all hard, but I know my choice.↓ ↓ ↓Read this newsletter for biz-buying insights from our private community of owners → https://lnkd.in/gZgZ3XMk"

Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: I heard a story about an entrepreneur making $20k/month... Selling framed tweets.  Here’s the breakdown:  • $49 a pop • 75% of sales were made as gifts • 0 employees (aside from himself)  Zach Katz, a film graduate from Boston, really didn’t want to get a normal job.  A conversation with a man selling $5 Sudoku puzzles on the street changed his life.   He realized: “If some guy selling Sudoku puzzles on the street could eke out a living, anything’s possible.”  The idea came to him while literally scrolling Twitter: What if you could frame a tweet?  He thrifted some frames, printed out tweets, and started selling on the streets of Portland.  Here's how it went...  Phase 1: Shift to online  Zach started off selling in person. Unsuccessfully. So he invested in building a Shopify store.  His first online launch netted ~$5,000 in sales – and features on sites like Product Hunt.  Phase 2: Scalable Marketing  Eventually, traffic from the press died down.  So, Zach began running Instagram ads & hired a marketing agency.  From that, Framed Tweets generated: • $20k in Year 1 • $110k in Year 2 • $20k+/mo in the first few months of Year 3  During the scaling phase, Katz met business partners in super interesting ways. He found: • A marketing agency from a Reddit post • Help with an influencer campaign from a Tinder date • A fulfillment center via referral from an unhappy customer  Phase 3: Things go downhill...  Zach spent $10k flying to the Grammys for a marketing stunt. His plan: • Gift his product to celebrities • They post about it on their socials • Take photos to use as promo material  Problem: the ROI was pretty much $0.  It drained Katz’s savings.  Phase 4: Acquisition  Other bad financial decisions (including paying influencers that didn’t sell any product) left Katz without capital.  The business was grossing $5-6k/mo.  Eventually, Katz sold the company.  This may not be a success story, but I love:  • The pure hustle. Choosing hard.  • The source of inspiration (sudoku guy on the street). Money is everywhere.  • Ending with an exit, not shutting down. A business is never worth $0. (Even a weird tweet-framing business.)↓ ↓ ↓If you like stories like this, you’d enjoy my newsletter → https://lnkd.in/eGmtANrR

Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: This artist has one of the most fascinating money-making stories I’ve ever heard.  • Worth $150M • Sold more records than One Direction • Has reportedly only left her house TWICE in the last decade  Enya.  Either you know her from the classics that struck your heart through the 80s and 90s... or you know her from her from TikTok.  Because Enya got a bit of “the Kate Bush treatment.” Ie, her 80s songs got re-introduced to Gen Z via viral TikTok sounds.  Where she differs from Kate Bush?  Enya has almost 4x more money.  And the oddest part...  Throughout her whole career, she's NEVER toured. Which is the top revenue stream for the vast majority of musical artists.  She claims it would be nearly impossible to recreate her complicated sound live.  Which may be true.  But the more likely answer?  She’s a total recluse: • She doesn’t enjoy live performances or interviews • She’s had some TERRIBLE stalker issues throughout her career  So, she lives in a castle in Ireland with her cats and a handful of staff, doesn't see anyone else, and works on her art.  But this begs the question:  If she doesn't tour, doesn't leave the house, and hasn't had a hit song since the early 2000s...  How did she make $150M?  She’s sold over 75 million albums worldwide, but that’s not the whole story.  The bulk of her wealth has come from one song: "Only Time."  But more importantly, it comes from who used it…  Times “Only Time” was used commercially: • A 2002 episode of Friends • A 2013 Volvo commercial • Deadpool 2 in 2018 • The 2022 Thor movie • A mac & cheese commercial 4yrs ago • Plus sports games, memes, & more  She gets royalty money from these.  But the real legacy behind this song:  CNN and other US news outlets used "Only Time" for 9/11 footage in 2001.  Enya’s response? To release it as a charity single.  She donated the $461k made to NY's firefighter charities.  She’s no doubt a weird lady, but I respect her: She built her success with obsession.  Once when asked about her romantic life, she said:  “I had partners. But I’m too much devoted to my music. Some people think it sounds sad but believe me, I’m happy. I am my music.”  The lesson I take?  Obsession comes with sacrifices. Few will understand. Is it worth it for you?  If it is, obsessing = success  I’ll leave you with this contrarian quote from Enya:  “My private lifestyle bothers a lot of people. I don’t like anybody else’s opinion. Post Text: I just learned about some creators who built a $150 MILLION streaming service in 4yrs.  How were they able to succeed where every past streaming company failed?  By avoiding all mistakes of their predecessors.  Here's the founding story of Nebula:  Lesson #1: No Venture Funding  Taking venture funding means you need to grow at all costs.  There's a graveyard of companies in this space for this reason: • Quibi ($1.75B in funding) • Vessel ($132.5M in funding) • Fullscreen (~$500M in reported funding)   By not taking venture funding, Nebula was able to: • Grow on their own terms • Align with creators by sharing funds • Not rely on paid ads to generate initial customers  Lesson #2: Putting Creators First  Nebula developed a system where: • 50% of Nebula profits went to creators • 50% of Nebula would be distributed to creators if the platform was sold  For the first time, creators would have ownership in a platform's success.  This system helped Nebula at 3 levels: • Short-term: Gained creator trust • Mid-term: Allocated profits to creators • Long-term: Made it a win-win scenario whenever the platform exited   Lesson #3: Launched with a Strategy  Nebula didn't want a massive launch. They wanted a small alpha group to answer key questions:  • What content did viewers care about? • What marketing messages resonated? • How did the users find the product/experience?  On May 23, 2019, they launched via an ad read from one of their creators: Isaac Arthur.  The launch brought in 4500 signups. More than enough to serve as a beta group.  But still no money for marketing.  They needed a growth strategy...  Lesson #4: Strategically Hacked Growth  The biggest problem for Nebula in the early days: Cashflow.  As a bootstrapped business, they had nothing to spend on ads.  The unlock: A bundle partnership with Curiosity Stream.  Curiosity Stream was already advertising with many of their creators.  They approached them with a deal:  Every customer that signs up for Curiosity Stream would get access to Nebula.  The bundle: • Increased value for customers • Raised conversion for both platforms  The partnership was a success. So much so, Curiosity Stream acquired a stake in Nebula at a valuation of ~$50M.  This enabled Curiosity Stream to: • Build their own streaming tech • Spend more on their originals • Grow out their team   Lesson #5: Stayed Flexible  Eventually, they knew they could pivot to direct marketing. They'd proven the product was valuable... And they needed cashflow.  They went from $0 adspend to $500k per month, while maintaining positive cashflow.   I'm a massive fan of this story: • Building based on past failures • Growth hacky sh*t for early traction • Aligning incentives to create long-term growth  A playbook on entering a supposedly "unbeatable" space.

Post Text: The best business model in the world:  Unlocking free $$$.  This startup raised $26M to help hotels & resorts generate free revenue – without them doing any extra work.  It's a hack Uber, Airbnb, & Postmates have all unlocked.  How does it work? Let's break it down.  What do all these companies have in common?  They connect underutilized resources with people who need them - without owning those resources themselves.  ie, Airbnb connects a traveler to a person with an empty home. But Airbnb doesn't own the home.  This business model is genius because it means companies (like Airbnb) "borrow" resources for free to provide a certain customer experience.  They're great for the economy too because they unlock $$$ from resources that weren't previously being used by anyone.  So how did this $26M startup find a space within this "marketplace" biz model?  They looked at hotels & resorts.  To begin with: • Most hotel gyms, pools, and spas are heavily underutilized by guests • But lots of people would love to use a hotel's amenities without shelling out for an overnight stay  Enter: ResortPass.  It's a platform for hotels & resorts to sell day passes for their facilities.  They work with the hotel to determine an appropriate price – then take a cut of each booking.  With these day passes, users can access amenities like pools, spas & fitness centers for 1 day.  So, say you live in Miami in a building with no pool access and have friends in town. You can grab a day pool pass at a premium hotel for $30/each, or even rent out your own cabana.  Meanwhile, the hotel's getting basically free $$$ for minimal extra work.  Clever, right?  It's a recession-friendly biz model too: • Hotels get extra $ in slow seasons • Users get a budget-friendly, local luxury experience  But ResortPass isn't just a marketplace - it's also building the very software for hotels to manage day guests...  Which reveals a brilliant biz model:  They earn revenue both by taking a fee from each visitor AND from the hotels that subscribe to its booking software.  Some quick stats & facts: • They've got 900+ hotels & resorts on the platform (including Ritz Carlton, Four Seasons, and Hyatt) • 1.6M+ users have booked day passes • They raised $26M late last year from investors including Jessica Alba & Gwyneth Paltrow  I love win-win businesses like this: • Users get access to new things • Companies get an extra revenue stream • The platform makes money from connecting the two (without investing in the facilities themselves)  Makes me wonder what other opportunities like these we've been overlooking...↓ ↓ ↓PS: If you like stories like this, you'll love my newsletter → https://lnkd.in/g3smakQm

Author: Codie A. Sanchez
Post Text: "You’ll own nothing, and you’ll like it."  An odd battle cry from a group of humans who in fact own much.  A bit Buddha, a bit Marx, a lot offbeat.  Perhaps they guessed the mood wrong. In an age of minimalism, they thought they’d hit their mark. But we humans have long needed a small nest of “our own.” A place to tend to, a garden to grow, a home.  Unlike herds on the plains of Africa, we are not great stewards for land unowned. There is a word for this truth, created all the way back in 1933:   The tragedy of the commons.  An economic phrase that means when all have access and none have ownership, things tend to get depleted and fall apart.  You need look no further than our oceans in international waters, housing projects, or public bathrooms for a real visual.  So if you believe one thing in all the many things I tell you I hope it's this…   Ownership is in fact the most important thing you can have.  It need not be in companies or land but it needs to be in something. Something that works even when you are not, something that gives even when you don’t.  Remember, SOMEONE must own. Post Text: Divorce is awful.   Here’s true lessons from going through it...  1. Marrying well is the biggest life hack of all.  2. Marrying poorly is a costly path to misery. Choose wisely.  3. When someone gets divorced I often say, “I’m sorry and congratulations.” Usually there is pain and freedom.  4. Money makes people a shell of themselves during divorce, do not fall to that level. You can make more money later.  5. There is always an exit tax on freedom, expect it.  6. Careful of shadow influences, people who whisper in the ear of your former spouse fear and pain that can take an amicable divorce and turn it into a nightmare.  7. Find someone who has walked the path before you, taboo subjects will leave you feeling lonely and alone.  8. It is going to be ok. If you learn from this, you will be better. And likely so will your spouse.  9. Mediation, arbitration, trial. Avoid trial at all costs, try for mediation. Cheaper, faster, less contentious.  10. Find an attorney who lists on their website they help do divorce amicably, if one spouse has a wartime attorney, it will turn into war. Try to avoid that.  11. Grab your loved ones close. A place to stay, a friend to wake up to, a person to watch movies into the night.  12. Don’t allow anyone to shame you. Of course you wanted it to work, hopefully you tried hard. Weak   Buy a biz with poor competition. When was the last time you got a plumber:  • On time  • With automated billing  • Who sent follow-up texts? Post Text: These guys created & sold a MONSTER $125M revenue business… Because they were sick of taking off their wedding rings.  LeBron even used their product while signing his Lakers contract. Here’s the story:   Friends KC & Ted, both aspiring actors, were working as waiters. They'd each gotten married the prior year.  In passing conversation, they realized:  Working in restaurants, going to the gym, etc meant they were always taking their rings off – or not wearing them.  An idea struck…  They wanted to show commitment to their wives – but in a practical way.  So, QALO (Quality Athletics Love Outdoors) was born: an everyday, durable ring.  Neither KC nor Ted had any experience in jewelry, manufacturing, or eCommerce…  Which didn’t stop them in the slightest.  They got to work designing & prototyping: • Choosing the right materials • Getting intros to manufacturers • Iterating for months before mass production  (Still newlyweds at this point. I wonder how emptying their savings for that first batch of rings went down..)  Now, let’s note: Their initial designs were quite bad.  But their main aim was to validate the market & see if others faced their problem. It didn't actually matter how they LOOKED (yet).  The lesson here: Don't bother optimizing what doesn’t need to be optimized.  Once they had inventory, they started emailing people who’d get the most use out of a silicon wedding ring: • NFL players • Firefighters • Military  ..Including KC’s college-friend-turned-NFL-quarterback, Andy Dalton.  Sending the product to Dalton sparked a wild chain of event:  First, players in Dalton’s locker room took notice & bought rings for themselves.  Second, the Cincinnati Bengals (Dalton’s team) featured on HBO’s Hard Knocks.  They did a whole segment on Dalton wearing a QALO ring.  This blew them up.   So they picked up their marketing: • Paying ambassadors (only people who actually used the product though) • Sending influencers the product for free • Hiring an agency for Facebook ads • Creating video content  In their 1st year, QALO made $60k.  In their 2nd, $3.2M.  Wild.  They went on to sell rings through: • REI • Target • Dick’s Sporting Goods  And had customers that included: • LeBron • Bryce Harper • Stephen Curry  It’s safe to say: they created an entire new industry.  Eventually, in 2019, they sold the biz. They’d generated $125M+ in total revenue by that point.  One piece of advice from the founders stuck with me:  "Stay true to your ‘why.’"  Remember your core vision for the world.  And don’t chase shiny objects if they don’t align with why you started.

Post Text: Our businesses did an expense analysis.  Here’s how we cut costs by 16%:  1. Set a goal in a meeting w/ your leaders...  Come up with a number. I said 20% as baseline, and we ended up around 16.6%. Which is actually a lot.  In one biz, monthly expenses were $600k, so that’s $96k less we spend now MONTHLY. $1.15M/yr in savings.  2. P&L Review  Look at each unit's P&L. Find the total amount that needs to be cut to hit the goal.  • If you have managers, let them do the first cuts since they’re closest to ops • If it’s just you, break down each biz unit  3. Dues & Subscriptions  Subscriptions & reoccurring costs are the first things to bloat. We cut 3 ways:  • The number of seats • The number of tools • Renegotiate rates  Found revenue: $5-20k  4. Find the living dead  Google does an annual spring cleaning where they shut down underperforming projects. They've killed 293 to date.  We killed dozens of zombie projects across my businesses in this process: • A newsletter • A community • A consulting offer • A physical product line  5. Contractors  Next area to negotiate, cut, or change.  We took in-house ads for one biz that saved us $4k+ of ad spend.  We rolled off a “nice to have” consultant.  We cut a few underperforming contractors & gave 50% to current team members to take on more work.  6. Employees  I pride myself on never *at least not yet* having layoffs in any of my portfolio companies based on the market. We grow, but not too aggressively, exactly for that reason.  BUT underperformers do get cut.  I use the "Splinter Effect" here:  Ask managers: who do you routinely find yourself having to “fix” things for? If the same name comes up more than 1x a month, you have your answer.  7. Cut, Automate, Delegate, Outsource  We had someone who made $80k/yr manually posting on socials. Outsource a VA at $12-20k, automate where possible.  “We’ve always done it this way" is not an excuse.  8. Turn it into a game  We gave a $1k bonus to anyone who came up with an idea (we actually implement) to use AI to cut a task we currently did manually.  9. Fall Cleaning:  Only thing I would do differently is to schedule this annually & processize.  So now it's on our Q4 agenda yearly.  10. Cutting isn’t ALWAYS smart  What businesses did we not do this with?  We are actively incubating 3 companies & they need more resources. Post Text: How to buy a biz & have the seller pay:  (kind of)  There's a method called Seller Financing.  It's where you as the buyer use future profits from the business to pay the seller.  Sounds great for you, right?  But why would a seller want to agree to something that makes it sound like THEY have to pay?  Negotiation is key.  Here are 3 things you can say to a seller to sway them:  1. You’ll raise the overall price.  If you were financed through a loan, you'd be paying likely around 8% in interest. To the bank.  With seller financing, the interest rate would likely be closer to 5%. And it would go straight to the seller.  So the interest rate is LOWER, allowing you more wiggle room for a higher overall price.  AND the seller gets that interest money straight to their pocket.  2. Their taxes will be spread out.  Let's say a seller owes $70k in taxes from the sale.  In a traditional deal, they owe it all at once.  With seller financing, you can write in terms to spread it out over, say, 10 years. So they'd pay ~$7k once a year.  3. It can be really f*cking fast.  SBA loans regularly take up to 90 days to clear. It's mostly out of your hands.  Seller financing? Can happen within 1 week if everyone's motivated to make it happen.  ↓ ↓ ↓  Not EVERY deal will work out this way.  But, the first step to get ANY deal to work this way is to learn the ins and outs of seller financing.This is one of the number 1 questions I get asked, so we finally created a course on it.It should answer any question you have about seller financing / self-liquidating acquisitions.We have a waiting list if you want to be the first to get access.Get it here → https://lnkd.in/exyKBftq

Learn Earn Invest Diversify Divest Repeat  Step 1: Learn  People overcomplicate financial basics. I remember I was burnt on a few early deals. For each mistake I made, I've never made it again.  Early scars are valuable. Post Text: There's a $10B company that controls half of the internet's advice.  Maybe that's a bit of an exaggeration, but they do around ~800 MILLION page views every single month.  That's wild.  Here's a list of websites you've probably visited before:  → The Points Guy for credit card reviews → Healthline.com to see if you're dying from any small health inconvenience → Lonely Planet for where to travel and what to do → MyMove.com to measure the hell that is moving houses  They all share one commonality. They realized the power of sites that captured intent. (Ie. People go to Lonely Planet not to browse but because they are traveling)  • Instead of having to make low $$ deals from spammy display ads, Red Venture's portfolio was primed for affiliate deals  • By partnering with providers (credit cards for The Points Guy, moving companies for MyMove.com), Red Ventures could now capitalize on their monopoly over intent by charging these providers for every lead they sent them.  This strategy has worked perfectly for Red Ventures:  - $11.5B+ valuation - Annual revenue of > $2B - Acquisitions of CNET for $500million and Lonely Planet for $50million  Here’s why I think this was so brilliant:  They found a powerful niche (sites that captured intent), broke the frame with a new monetization strategy (affiliate deals > display ads), and built their moat by acquiring the best-in-class sites.

Post Text: This skincare brand did $48M in revenue in year 1...  Their secret? Leveraging AI.   Spoiled Child was an anti-aging and skin care brand founded in 2022.   But they didn’t want to launch like any other DTC brand..  Ecommerce has been facing a massive fall in conversion rates, as social media is saturated with ads.  How do you capture attention in such a saturated market? Personalize the experience.  So Spoiled Child used AI to deliver.   They captured over 250,000 data points from focus groups & customer data from their sister brand IL Makiage. They created a two-minute questionnaire from this data.  It asked users about their preferences, age, problems... Then be matched with a hyper-personalized serum solution.   That’s cool, but how did they drive traffic in the first place?   By applying new branding that legacy brands in the anti-aging space just haven’t matched:  • Typically, anti-aging brands focus on treatment and maintenance (wrinkle-fixing cream, etc) • But Spoiled Child went for 25-55 year old customers focused on prevention (collagen pills, etc).  Then, they spent $10 million on subway takeovers, billboards, and digital ads with copy like, “Your routine is getting old” and “Stay immature. Intelligent skin & hair products that refuse to take aging seriously.”  A beautiful example of counter-positioning and reaching a new customer segment.

Post Text: Why do you think so small?I sit at Bill Perkins' massive compound overlooking the lake. The hedge fund manager knows a lot about making millions & taking big bets. He just bet a guy $200k on who would lose more body fat.But today, I’m here for his advice. He looks at me and my husband and says, “You’ve been investing in small businesses so long, small has infected your thinking.”I took a deep breath. He’s right.“You need to shed all the bullshit, or you’ll never be truly big.” Ugh. That kind of hurts. There are so many levels to this game of business. As you’re growing, you’ll realize you keep outgrowing yourself and the games you used to play.The biggest life hack isn’t a tactic or a tool. It’s a way of thinking. Bill thinks in billions. I think millions.What would happen if you just added a zero or two to the potential of the ideas in your head? I think that is the difference between being a world changer, or not.↓ ↓ ↓I don't really mind being bullied by billionaires. I usually end up better for it.If you want more tales where my rich mentors gave the right advice at the right time, I compiled a few of these stories in this week's newsletter.Who knows, maybe it'll be the right advice at the right time for you, too.Get it here, free↓
